channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: The Australia-Indonesia pact won’t shift the regional balance
item.description: But this diplomatic win for Australia does reflect warm neighbourly ties.

item.title: U.S. Allies Turn Against Trump’s Drug Boat War
item.description: Western partners are distancing themselves from the U.S. operation.

item.title: The US-China fentanyl deal will not stop America’s opioid crisis
item.description: Synthetic drug makers can adapt faster than governments regulate, rendering precursor bans at best short-term respite.

item.title: Making Sense of the World Energy Outlook
item.description: The energy transition is not inevitable—but neither is business as usual.

item.title: Major Corruption Scandal Undermines Ukraine’s War Effort
item.description: An investigation found that politicians and other powerful individuals received kickbacks that could have undercut Kyiv’s ability to defend itself from Russia.

item.title: With Help From New Tactics and Drones, Russia Closes in on Another Ukrainian City
item.description: Russia is increasingly sophisticated in using and defending against drones in urban areas.

item.title: Ethiopia’s Fight Against Anti-Abortion Propaganda
item.description: How Ethiopians are resisting U.S.-backed disinformation on abortions.

item.title: The Voice of Venezuela’s Opposition
item.description: María Corina Machado won the Nobel Peace Prize—but the fight for democracy is far from over.

item.title: How Venezuela Fits Into Trump’s Strategy for Latin America
item.description: And how the region is navigating a changed United States.

item.title: Brazil Tries to Keep Climate Cooperation Alive
item.description: At COP30, the global energy transition is moving forward without the United States.

item.title: The U.S. President Should Practice for a Nuclear Crisis
item.description: The commander in chief gets almost no preparation for the ultimate decision. That needs to change.

item.title: How Indigenous Peoples Will Drive Progress at COP30
item.description: As co-hosts for this year's United Nations Climate Change Conference in Belém, the Indigenous peoples and local communities of Brazil’s Amazon region understand what is at stake and will be given a greater voice than ever before. That is good news not only for these communities, but for everyone.

item.title: Why Thieves Like to Steal Art
item.description: Suspects are being held in the Louvre heist, but artifacts are still missing.

item.title: Scaling the Ocean Economy
item.description: The ocean is a critical ally in efforts to tackle climate change, ensure food security, and support livelihoods. But delivering the level of sustained, coordinated investment needed to harness its potential requires a strategic approach that leverages public and philanthropic capital to establish a pipeline of investable projects.

item.title: The rise and rise of geopolitical risk
item.description: Volatile geopolitics creates risks for business. A new industry is emerging in Australia to meet the demand for intelligence and advice.

item.title: A Turning Point for Clean Energy
item.description: Water, wind, and solar power are already transforming economies around the world, but the green transition remains fragile. To translate the current momentum into lasting gains, governments must invest in critical infrastructure that fuels job creation and supports sustainable growth.

item.title: Washington Must Confront Abu Dhabi Over Sudan
item.description: If Trump truly wants to be a peacemaker, he should banish the UAE from the negotiating table.

item.title: Libya’s Oil Corruption Is Bad for Business
item.description: International firms should address graft before participating in a deeply compromised sector.

item.title: How to Measure Climate Progress
item.description: Ending reliance on oil, coal, and gas, and embracing technologies that will only improve and become cheaper over time, is not just smart climate policy. It is the best way to improve economic competitiveness and human prosperity for decades to come.

item.title: Mexico’s surprising record on murder
item.description: Claudia Sheinbaum’s security strategy is working. She has a mountain to climb

item.title: How to avoid Africa’s next war
item.description: Pressure from America and its allies can prevent a return to fighting

item.title: China’s creepiest export surge
item.description: Countries are queuing to buy the tools and techniques of the CCP’s security state

item.title: Elon Musk’s $1trn pay deal highlights companies’ superstar dilemma
item.description: Can firms hedge against losing key talent?

item.title: The 10-4 rule for interacting with customers
item.description: Is Target’s new policy bonkers, businesslike or a bit of both?

item.title: TSMC’s cautious expansion is frustrating the AI industry
item.description: The Taiwanese chipmaking giant has been burned by previous investment booms

item.title: Libellous chatbots could be AI’s next big legal headache
item.description: Companies from Google and Meta to OpenAI are getting sued for defamation

item.title: Ethiopia is perilously close to another war
item.description: Conflict in Tigray could balloon into a regional conflagration

item.title: The dangers beneath Gaza’s rubble
item.description: The devastated strip may have more unexploded bombs than anywhere in the world

item.title: Japanese women are wrestling with sumo’s boundaries
item.description: Might a female prime minister break a long-standing taboo on entering the ring? Don’t count on it

item.title: Asia’s most treacherous sailing season
item.description: Rohingya refugees are risking their lives in perilous sea crossings. Some do not make it

item.title: China’s growing global fan club
item.description: Our new poll shows global opinion is swinging its way

item.title: The way Uyghurs speak Mandarin is now a joke
item.description: For many it’s not funny, given the political heat around language choices

item.title: Parents on e-bikes are transforming the school run
item.description: They’re smug, snug and often faster than drivers

item.title: Florida is running a radical experiment in education
item.description: State cash and “unbundled” schools offer parents wide choices

item.title: Why the Democrats may lose again to Donald Trump
item.description: One congressman’s choice not to run again is a dire signal for them, and about politics in general

item.description: Can New Mexico’s experiment work where others have failed?

item.description: A weak-currency policy is punishing consumers and storing up financial risk

item.description: It has the world’s most undervalued currency and one of its biggest trade surpluses

item.description: We pit two heavyweights against each other

item.title: Kerala can teach India a thing or two about social welfare
item.description: But it also has plenty to learn about economic dynamism

item.title: A bombing in Delhi raises tensions in the region
item.description: But India’s restrained response suggests that is little immediate risk of hostilities with Pakistan

item.title: Twin Blasts in South Asia and the Region’s Dangerous Dilemmas
item.description: The region increasingly resembles a powder keg — one spark away from catastrophe.

item.title: Trump’s ‘War on Drugs’ Will Work About as Well as the Last One
item.description: You can’t bomb your way out of an illicit market.

item.title: A New Path to Middle East Security
item.description: How the Gulf can become the fulcrum of a new Middle East order.

item.title: Can Democracy Still Make a Comeback?
item.description: Hope for a freer future is dimmed but not lost.

item.title: Can Positive Change Happen from Within in Afghanistan Under the Taliban?
item.description: Attempts to impose rapid change from outside have repeatedly failed. International actors must not substitute Afghan agency, but enable it.

item.title: As COP30 Discusses Climate Action, Indian Capital Sees Pollution Protests
item.description: Following protests against severe pollution, India’s main opposition leader upheld “the right to clean air” as “a basic human right.” Will pollution finally become a political issue in India?

item.title: Preparing for when disaster and conflict converge
item.description: What Australia must learn for its defence posture following record flooding and typhoons in Vietnam and the Philippines.

item.title: Australia and Indonesia to Sign ‘Watershed’ Defense Treaty in January
item.description: The agreement marks a high-point in the bilateral relationship, but stops short of marking a significant strategic reorientation on the part of Jakarta.

item.title: Albania’s AI-generated minister is impressive spectacle, questionable reform
item.description: Behind the glossy digital image lies deeper concerns about governance, corruption, and how political performance shapes policy.

item.title: Thailand-Cambodia Peace Deal on the Brink After Clash in Disputed Border Settlement
item.description: The incident, which Cambodia says left one civilian dead, comes two days after a Thai soldier was reportedly injured by a landmine explosion at the border.

item.title: “Anchored in the region” – What the new Australia–Indonesia security treaty really means
item.description: The pact strengthens trust between neighbours who don’t always agree, without abandoning Indonesia’s non-alignment.

item.title: Nigeria vs. Trump
item.description: How Nigerians are responding to the U.S. president’s threat to attack “guns-a-blazing.”

item.title: Congress Prepares to End Record-Breaking U.S. Shutdown
item.description: Republicans hope to push through a funding package that excludes extended Affordable Care Act subsidies.

item.title: 43 Days Later: Congress to Vote on Funding Bill to End U.S. Shutdown
item.description: Republicans hope to push through a funding package that excludes extended Affordable Care Act subsidies.

item.title: Shutdown Deal Gives Laid-Off U.S. Diplomats Hope for Reprieve
item.description: The continuing resolution could postpone the end for some State Department employees on leave.

item.title: Back-to-Back Blasts Rock India and Pakistan
item.description: The two incidents underscore growing risks to regional stability.

item.title: South Korea’s Semiconductor Dependence Is Becoming a Structural Economic Risk
item.description: Persistent export concentration around memory chips leaves the Korean economy acutely vulnerable to global tech cycles.

item.title: Gaza’s zombie ceasefire
item.description: Neither an Arab reconstruction plan nor an American one have much chance of success

item.description: A frenzy of financial innovation has ensnared America Inc. What could go wrong?

item.description: Alarmed by Beijing’s rare earths chokehold, Washington is scrambling to plug other potential vulnerabilities.

item.title: Legal Pathways Will Save Rohingya Lives
item.description: Creating a pathway toward third-country resettlement is the only practical way to stop refugees from dying at sea.

item.title: Destruction in the Heart of Old Samarkand
item.description: Forced evictions began in the spring in the neighborhood adjacent to the modest al-Maturidi mausoleum. Then the demolition began.

item.title: Can the NBA Help Heal China-US Relations?
item.description: As China-U.S. tensions rise, sports diplomacy offers a path back to healthy competition.

item.description: History, ideology, and realism all contribute to the perception that Trump’s recent mention of the G-2 is just a U.S. “trap.”

item.description: Fentanyl is hard to kick. Particularly as a source of leverage

item.description: The Nexperia case offers a sobering tale for the future of European technological competitiveness.

item.title: Trumpforce
item.description: The president is putting together his own police force to operate in cities, with few legal constraints

item.title: Sperm whales communicate with vowels
item.description: The clicks that the animals make share at least one property with human language

item.title: Why Did Asian Countries Give Trump So Much on Trade?
item.description: The new deals contain unusual concessions that could change the flow of goods in Asia.

item.title: Trump’s Foreign Economic Policy in Disarray
item.description: In South America, US President Donald Trump’s administration is heavily exposed to a dubious effort to stabilize Argentina’s peso, while in Asia it is engaged in an on-again-off-again trade war with China, in which China has the upper hand. The administration seems determined to create problems for the US where none existed.

item.title: Chile Is Making an Unprecedented Right Turn
item.description: It’s Latin America’s traditional beacon of stability—and its next country to vote for the far right.

item.description: It’s Latin America’s traditional beacon of stability—and its next country to vote for the far right.

item.description: Will Manila shake off its “deputy sheriff” badge to become the anchor of a new coalition in Southeast Asia?

item.description: A visit to the city offering more than $40,000 for second children

item.title: Tajikistan’s Glaciers Are Collapsing While the Government Talks Green
item.description: A mismatch between eco-friendly government rhetoric and polluting actions on the ground is exacerbating Tajikistan’s climate change vulnerability.

item.title: Will China Fill the Gap in Iran’s Defense Sector?
item.description: Insights from Can Kasapoğlu.

item.description:
EIU is using generative AI to enable clients to ask plain…

item.title: Doha Is Still Counting on Washington
item.description: After suffering two attacks, Qatar is doubling down on its security strategy.

item.title: Japan’s Takaichi Pushes Stricter Rules on Foreign Nationals
item.description: Regulations for foreign nationals in Japan became a major topic of debate in this year’s election. The new government is acting accordingly.

item.title: Uzbekistan: A Silk Mirage
item.description: An interview with Joanna Lillis on the contrasts between "new" and "old" Uzbekistan.

item.title: Japan’s Taiwan Policy Is Evolving – But Not Yet Transforming
item.description: Takaichi’s remarks stirred a firestorm, but her later clarifications highlight the limits on Japan’s involvement in a Taiwan crisis.

item.title: China Wants Teachers to Focus on Teaching, Not Paperwork
item.description: “Formalism” is dragging down China’s education sector. Will new policies help?

item.title: The Key to Unlocking Private Climate Finance
item.description: The path to a just clean-energy future runs through the private sector, but policy uncertainty continues to stifle innovation and investment. Only coherent policies that align the interests of investors, governments, and consumers can translate climate pledges into tangible progress that protects people and the planet.

item.title: Pakistan’s Afghan Retaliation Imminent After TTP’s Twin Attacks
item.description: Islamabad has run out of patience following the TTP’s suicide attack in Islamabad and the storming of a school for military cadets in Khyber Pakhtunkhwa.

item.title: Halting Africa’s Deforestation
item.description: Deforestation in Africa continues to outpace restoration efforts and is fast approaching a tipping point. To avoid reaching it, delegates at COP30 must adopt a more proactive and comprehensive strategy that focuses on improving agricultural productivity, urban planning, and living standards on the continent.

item.title: Even on Ukraine’s front line there is time, and a need, for beauty
item.description: Maryna Zhegulina risks her life to help soldiers keep their humanity

item.title: What Democracy Means for a Society’s Bottom Line
item.description: History and direct political experience suggest that if democracy and broad-based social and human development are to be sustainable, they must be pursued in tandem. When people are free to choose their leaders and hold them accountable, sustainable and inclusive growth become more likely.

item.title: How the exasperating, indispensable BBC must change
item.description: Its latest crisis needs to spur reforms to bolster its news division

item.title: PS Events: COP30 Studio Sessions
Trumponomics Will End in Tears
item.description: From Latin America to Turkey, the kind of economic populism US President Donald Trump is embracing has always led to disaster. Recent market signals suggest that America’s reckoning will arrive sooner rather than later – vindicating the economic-policy orthodoxy that today’s Trumpified Republican Party now repudiates.

item.title: Trump’s Year of Living Dangerously
item.description: How Trump's second term is reshaping America and the world.

item.title: The Folly of India’s Illiberal Hegemony
item.description: China gains from New Delhi’s support for South Asian autocrats.

item.title: Bangladesh’s Interim Government Bows to Islamists’ Pressure
item.description: It has gone against the country’s secular and creative spirit by scrapping the hiring of music and physical education teachers in primary schools.

item.title: A case for UN reform that cannot wait
item.description: The power, purpose, and the price of relevance for the global organisation at 80.

item.title: Time to Get Ready for the Era of ‘Selective Protectionism’
item.description: What Mexico’s tariff hike for non-FTA countries means for ASEAN and beyond.
